abstract.p: List of upcoming benefit events in New York

block.p: Remembering Broadway

MONDAY -- The Broadway Theater Institute will hold a benefit from 6 to 8 p.m. at Club New York, 252 West 43rd Street (Eighth Avenue). Awards will be given to several theater institutions, including the Shubert Organization, which will receive an award honoring its 100th anniversary. Presenters will include Kitty Carlisle Hart and James Lapine. Proceeds go to the institute's programs that preserve the history of live theater on Broadway, and for the plan it is formulating for the creation of a museum and learning center in the Theater District. Tickets, $50, (212) 956-5481.
Remembering Broadway

MONDAY -- The Broadway Theater Institute will hold a benefit from 6 to 8 p.m. at Club New York, 252 West 43rd Street (Eighth Avenue). Awards will be given to several theater institutions, including the Shubert Organization, which will receive an award honoring its 100th anniversary. Presenters will include Kitty Carlisle Hart and James Lapine. Proceeds go to the institute's programs that preserve the history of live theater on Broadway, and for the plan it is formulating for the creation of a museum and learning center in the Theater District. Tickets, $50, (212) 956-5481.
Honoring Senator Moynihan

THURSDAY -- Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan will be honored at a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria to raise money for scholarships at the New School University. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who is to become the university's new president when his Senate term concludes in January, will speak. Drinks at 6:30 will be followed by dinner at 7:30. Tickets, $500, from (212) 229-5662, ext. 250.
Dining Surrounded by Art

THURSDAY -- A preview of the annual International Fine Art Fair, at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street, will raise money for the social service programs of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House. Dinner will take place among the booths, and interior decorators will style tables to suggest the works of famous painters. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 5:30 dinner follows at 8. Tickets, $1,000, or $250 for the reception alone, from (212) 744-5022, ext. 1282.
So Children Breathe Easier

THURSDAY -- The Children's Allergy, Immunology and Respiratory Center will be supported by a spring dinner-dance at the New York Hilton. Dr. Max Gomez, medical correspondent on WNBC-TV, will be the master of ceremonies at the black-tie evening. The event will raise money for research, patient care and community education programs at the center, which is part of Weill Cornell Medical Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 6:30, with dinner and dancing to follow at 7:30. Dr. Arthur Klein will be honored for his work as the hospital's chief operating officer and executive vice president of the pediatrics department. Tickets, $300, from (212) 821-0560.
Picture Honors

THURSDAY -- Peter Jennings of ABC News will lead the 16th annual Infinity Awards given by the International Center for Photography. The event, at the Regent Wall Street Hotel, 55 Wall Street, begins with drinks at 6:30, followed by dinner and the awards. The honorees include Helmut Newton, James Nachtwey and Adam Fuss. The evening will benefit the museum's exhibition programs and its free photography education classes in the South Bronx, East Harlem and Hell's Kitchen. Tickets, $500, from (212) 860-1777, ext. 141.
Sisters at the Plaza

THURSDAY -- The Catholic Big Sisters will hold its annual spring dinner and dance at the Plaza. The black-tie evening will begin at 6:30 p.m. with cocktails and a silent auction. The evening will benefit the agency's social services on the Lower East Side, including free family and student counseling, mentoring for students and adults, and classes in English as a second language. Tickets, $350, from (212) 838-2660, ext 16.
The Iris Ball

FRIDAY -- The Iris Ball, an annual dinner-dance to raise money for the Manhattan League of Helen Keller Services for the Blind, will be held at the St. Regis. The black-tie evening begins at 7 with drinks, followed by dinner at 8 and dancing to the Tom Harrington Orchestra. Tickets, $300, from (212) 285-7029, ext. 212.
Perpetuating Motion

NEXT SUNDAY -- Mikhail Baryshnikov and Laurie Anderson will be among those performing at a benefit for the new works fund of the Trisha Brown Dance Company. The event will take place at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue (19th Street). A Champagne reception at 5 p.m. will be followed by the performance at 7. Afterward, dinner will be served at the Matthew Marks Gallery, 523 West 24th Street. Transportation will be provided. Tickets are $1,000 or $75 and up for the performance alone, from (212) 582-0040.
Pops at Carnegie Hall

MAY 15 -- A benefit concert and dinner-dance will support the free summer concert series and educational programs of the New York Pops. The black-tie evening begins at 7:30 at Carnegie Hall with a musical tribute to Schuyler G. Chapin, the New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner. Dinner and dancing will follow at 10 at the Plaza. Tickets, $500, or $35 to $150 for the concert alone, from (212) 765-7677.
Aid for Homeless Women

MAY 15 -- Women in Need, which provides shelter and support services for homeless women and their children, will benefit from a dinner at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine. Joseph Cullman, the chairman emeritus of Philip Morris Companies, and his wife, Joan Cullman, a vice chairwoman of the Lincoln Center Theater, will be honored for their support. The evening begins with drinks at 6:30, with dinner to follow at 7:30. Students from the National Dance Institute and the Heritage Gospel Ensemble will perform. Tickets, $500, from (212) 838-6033.
Curtain Calls

MAY 15 -- Lauren Bacall and Brian Dennehy will be among those honored at a benefit for the 11 regional theaters of the National Corporate Theater Fund, including the Long Wharf in New Haven and Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, R.I. The black-tie event, at the Waldorf-Astoria, will begin with drinks at 6:30, with dinner to follow at 7:30. Members of the cast of ''Forbidden Broadway Strikes Back'' will perform. Tickets, $1,000, from (212) 888-7003.
Environmental Honors

MAY 15 -- Educational centers of the National Audubon Society, including those at the boathouse in Prospect Park and in Greenwich, Conn., will benefit from a dinner and dance at Pier 60, at Chelsea Piers. Marian S. Heiskell, Paul Tudor Jones II and Roy E. Disney will be honored for their environmental efforts. The black-tie evening begins with a cocktail reception at 6:30, with dinner and dancing to follow. Tickets, $600, from (212) 997-0100.
Aid at a Crucial Moment

MAY 15 -- Cast members of the Broadway musical ''Swing'' will perform at a benefit at the Waldorf-Astoria for the Ronald McDonald House of New York City. The house provides accommodation and support for the families of children who are in New York to undergo treatment for cancer and other serious diseases. Al Roker will be the master of ceremonies at the event, which begins with cocktails at 6:30. Dinner at 7:30 will be followed by the performance. Tickets, $600, (212) 245-6570.
A Century of Summers

MAY 16 -- The 100th anniversary of Yaddo, the summer colony for artists, in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., will be celebrated at a dinner at the University Club, 1 West 54th Street. The author Calvin Trillin will be the master of ceremonies, and Arthur Gelb, a former president of The New York Times Company Foundation, will be honored. The black-tie evening will begin at 7 with drinks and a silent auction, with dinner to follow at 8. Tickets are $500, from (518) 584-0746.
Protecting Women

MAY 16 -- Lesley Stahl of ''60 Minutes'' will speak at a benefit for the free crisis-intervention and counseling programs at the Mount Sinai Sexual Assault and Violence Intervention Program. The dinner, at the Sky Club, 200 Park Avenue (45th Street), will honor Linda Fairstein, the chief of the Sex Crimes Prosecution Unit of the Manhattan District Attorney's Office. The evening begins with cocktails at 6, with dinner to follow at 7. Tickets, $175, from (212) 423-2143.
Humanitarians in the Harbor

MAY 16 -- A dinner at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum with former President and Mrs. George Bush will raise money for AmeriCares, the humanitarian aid and disaster relief organization. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 6:30, with dinner and a performance by the United Nations International School Concert Choir to follow at 7:30. Ferries to Ellis Island leave from Battery Park beginning at 6. Tickets, $1,000, from (203) 972-5510.
